qas.question: Of what is yoga a part  in Indian philosophy?
To what school of Hindu philosophy is yoga aligned?
What concept does yoga accept the differentiates it from Samkhya?
How many of the six pramanas does yoga accept?
Unlike other schools of Samkhya, what attitude makes yoga different?
What philosophy is Yoga antithetical to?
What does Samkhya accept that yoga does not?
Which parts of Samkhya does Yoga reject?

context: In Indian philosophy, Yoga is among other things, the name of one of the six āstika <a0_0>philosophical schools<a0_0/>. The Yoga philosophical system is closely allied with the dualism premises of <a1_0><b5_0>Samkhya<b5_0/><a1_0/> school. The Yoga school accepts <b7_0>the Samkhya psychology and metaphysics<b7_0/>, but is considered <a4_0>theistic<a4_0/> because it accepts <b6_0>the concept of "<a2_0><b9_0>personal god<b9_0/><a2_0/>"<b6_0/>, unlike Samkhya. The epistemology of the Yoga school, like the Sāmkhya school, relies on <a3_0>three<a3_0/> of six prāmaṇas as the means of gaining reliable knowledge: <b8_0>pratyakṣa<b8_0/> (perception), anumāṇa (inference) and śabda (āptavacana, word/testimony of reliable sources).
